DOC.HEAD: Study Calls For Greater Teaching of Non-European Languages
DOC.TEXT: Although Japanese is the most rapidly growing foreign language course on American college campuses, a major national program is needed to offer non-European languages to more students, said a study released Wednesday. The study, conducted by Johns Hopkins University foreign language specialist Richard D. Lambert for the American Council on Education, said traditional West European languages are still the heavy favorites among university students. The study showed 20.4 percent of college students were studying Spanish, 16.8 percent French and 7.1 percent German in 1986 at 13 institutions surveyed. Italian was the choice of 2.4 percent and Russian the choice of 1.8 percent of university students surveyed. Japanese was picked by 2.2 percent of the students at 11 universities that offered it but ``has tripled in the last three or four years,'' Lambert told a news conference. ``I was surprised by the spread of the less commonly studied languages, particularly Japanese, Chinese, Russian and a little bit of Arabic,'' he said. Mandarin Chinese was being studied by 2.1 percent of students at 10 universities. Arabic was the choice of one-half of one percent of the students at five universities offering it. ``While you still get the bulk of students coming in and continuing in French, German and Spanish, you are getting some diffusion in the colleges, and in high schools,'' he said. ``Maybe 300 high schools teach Japanese and more teach Russian and Chinese.'' One of the problems, Lambert said, is that students ``take language in the 9th and 10th grades and then it goes fallow in the 11th and 12th grades and is not built upon at the college level.'' ``You have got a lot of students getting a little bit of language,'' he said. ``What is clearly needed for collegiate level foreign language teaching is a major national effort dedicated to introducing major change and upgrading the system.'' Federal funds for foreign language instruction, he said, go almost exclusively for programs to teach Defense Department personnel and other government employes. ``It is high time the nation invested the necessary private and public resources needed to advance foreign language instruction at the collegiate level,'' Lambert wrote in the study. The American Council on Education is a cluster of educational organizations and institutions. The study was funded by grants from the Ford Foundation, the Exxon Educational Foundation and the Pew Charitable Trusts.
